* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
This is Agnes V., a resident of Dasmariñas, Philippines. She is already a widow at 37 and the mother of four children, two of whom are in high school while one is in elementary and the other is staying home. By the grace of God, Agnes has single-handedly managed to support her older children's education up to high school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her two children all the way to college. A dream for most poor Filipino parents like Agnes as she herself has been a high school graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Agnes operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 Philippine pesos (PHP)-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Agnes earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling in piece rate. Agnes’ store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a 32,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  
Agnes dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to have her house expanded and renovated by the end of the year.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
This is Mercedita C., 44, a resident of Dasmariñas, Philippines. She is married to Ponciano C., a serviceman, and the proud mother of a teenage boy, now on his last few years of college education for a Bachelor of Science in Nursing. It is truly a dream come true for Mercedita as she herself possesses a college diploma and believes it is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Mercedita operates a variety store where she sells not only groceries but LPG (Liquefied Petroleum Gas) for fuel and cosmetics from the popular direct selling brands. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Philippine pesos (PHP) of cooking oil, or an egg. Juanita earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at piece rate. Mercedita’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 700 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a 16,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Mercedita dreams to be able to continue giving her son a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She also hopes to be able to help her community by serving them through her business.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes C., 56, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Bonifacio C., a taxi driver, they are blessed with three children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn money so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own cold cuts business for the past few years.

Lourdes has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her meat business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 15,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more quantities of products to be incorporated into her current product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can finally have a house of her own.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Adoracion

texts.en:
Adoracion J. is a 56-year-old married woman who lives in DSB, Pontevedra, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store business. Adoracion’s husband, Marino, aged 62, is a laborer and they have three children who are aged between 30 and 35. All her children have their own jobs and help their parents in defraying financial and other family expenses.

Adoracion joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve their family's quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a general store. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000 from her business activities.

Adoracion is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 was used to fund the operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing PHP 15,000 for her fourteenth cycle loan which she intends to use to invest in her general store business. Adoracion is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To provide additional working capital

loans.name: Lyn

texts.en:
Lyn J. is a 39-year-old married woman who lives in Zone 2 Brgy. Tabao, Valladolid. She earns her living by running a general store. Lyn’s husband, Nestor, is 45 years old and a fisherman, and they have two adult children.

Lyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve their family's quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a general store business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000 from her business activities.

Lyn is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 was used to fund the operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing PHP 19,000 for her sixteenth cycle loan which she intends to use to invest in her general store. Lyn is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To provide additional working capital

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena B., 40, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Wilson B., a landscaping artist, they are blessed in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn money so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own landscaping business for quite some time now.

Rowena has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her landscaping business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 50,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying supplies and other materials for their landscaping needs.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying supplies for a landscaping business

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia B. is a single woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: frozen foods and cosmetic products. She lives in Brgy. Andres, Bonifacio, Sagay City.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her frozen foods and cosmetic businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000.

Lilia is now borrowing PHP 25,000 so she can expand her frozen foods and cosmetics businesses. This will be her sixteenth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 25,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Lilia aspires to elevating her family’s living conditions and to ensuring their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To provide additional working capital

loans.name: Lhagvasuren

texts.en:
Lhagvasuren T., 26, lives with his wife and two children in an apartment in Uvs Province in western Mongolia. His son currently attends a local primary school, while his daughter is yet too young to go to kindergarten.

While his wife works as a dentist in town, Lhagvasuren operates a food-selling business which he purchased In 2009 with 20 million MNT. His commodity balance is now 15 million MNT, and he also plants seabuckthorn trees to sell, profits from which have allowed him to purchase a car.

Over the years Lhagvasuren has worked hard to build a stable business operation and has gained much experience. His business is very important to him and his family. He says, "I really want to expand my business and open a big wholesaling center in my town and am trying my best to achieve the goal. Plus, my only wish is to provide a good education for my children and to help them become good people. My wife and I are putting money in my children's savings."

Very hardworking and not easily discouraged, Lhagvasuren is a good and reliable client of XacBank and is now requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan to purchase more foods such as pastries, cookies, candy, fruit, flour and rice to sell in the business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for his store

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita C. is a 42-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy. Andres, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store. Pacita’s husband, Efren, is a quarry leadman and they have three adult children who already work to help defray their family's living expenses.

Pacita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve their family's quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her general store. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 11,000 from her business activities.

Pacita is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 11,000 was used to fund the operations of her general store, and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing PHP 14,000 for her current loan which she intends to use to invest in her general store. Pacita is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To provide additional working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase diary products

loans.name: Hikoyat

texts.ru: Назридинова Хикоят проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 56 лет. Вдова, имеет одного ребенка. Образование среднее. Более 2 лет занимается торговлей. У нее магазин, где она продает продукты питания. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Hikoyat N. lives in the Shahrituz region. She is 56 years old. She is a widow and has one child. She has secondary education and has been in the retail business for more than two years. She has a store where she sells groceries. She is asking for a loan to increase sales.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase sales

loans.name: Noor Jahan's Group

texts.en:
Noor Jahan lives in Multan with her family. They own a small house of two rooms and have been living in it for the past ten years. She is involved in the boutique business, selling embroidered and stitched dresses. Her variety of clothes attracts customers to her boutique. She has been doing this work for over six years. Her client base is purely women. She prepares women's wear such as embroidered shalwar kamiz and stitched kurtas. These two garments are famous in Pakistan because women love to wear these dresses, not just for special occasions but also as everyday wear.

She sells her goods within her neighborhood and also to the clothing shops, delivering the finished products to the designated places. She also sells bangles to earn extra income, but that is not her primary business.

Noor Jahan has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). With the loan amount she will buy materials like clothes, threads, and beads in bulk. She will also hire a worker to help her fulfill the larger orders in time.

She is hopeful that she will be able to bring positive financial changes to her family.

loans.use: To purchase required materials for a boutique business.

loans.name: Nurjan's Group

texts.en:
Nurjan S. is the leader of the group. She is 59 and married. She has raised four daughters; all of them are married and live separately with their families. Eight years ago, with an initial investment of 15,000 soms ($326) Nurjan opened a shop and began to sell convenience goods and different clothes. In this way, she earns 15,000 soms ($326) per month. With money received from the loan, Nurjan wants to purchase convenience goods to resell. In the future, she plans to purchase a yurt to accept tourists.

Zholdoshbek B. is 43 and married. Five years ago, with an initial investment of 5,000 soms, he began to sell dairy products and Kyrgyz national drinks. In this way, he earns 25,000 soms ($543.47) per month. That profit made it possible for him to improve his living conditions and to be able to pay for his children’s education. Now Zholdoshbek is applying for a loan because he needs money to purchase 500 liters of national drinks in order to resell them and make some money.

Zhyidekan N. is the treasurer of group. She is 30 and married. They have three daughters and a son. Two older daughters study at school and the others are not yet in school. Ten years ago Zhyidekan got married, and since that moment she and her husband began to breed livestock. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase five farm animals to increase the number of livestock.

Rahima B. is 34 and a widow. She has raised a daughter and a son; both of them are at school. Rahima’s parents work in the hotel business, and five years ago after her husband’s passing, they helped her to open her own business. With the initial investment of 10,000 soms ($217.40), Rahima began to accept tourists near lake Son Kol. She earns 10,000 soms ($217.40) per month and now she wants to get a loan to purchase four farm animals to increase the number of livestock. With the rest of the money, she plans to buy convenience goods.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To purchase convenience goods to sell

loans.name: Barot

texts.ru: Султонов Барот проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 65 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Образование среднее. Более 12 лет занимается растениеводством. Он в основном выращивает овощи и фрукты. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений. Барот хочет получить хороший урожай и вынести на рынок.
texts.en:
Barot S. lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 65 years old, he is married and has six children. He has secondary education. He has been in agriculture for more than twelve years. He mainly grows fruits and vegetables. He is taking out the loan to buy mineral fertilizer. Barot wants to collect a good harvest and sell it on the market.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Surriya's Group

texts.en:
Surriya sells shawls in order to increase her family's financial comfort. She has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) to expand her business selling shawls (a fabric square worn by women over the shoulders or head).

She lives in the city of Multan, which is famous in Pakistan for its sweetmeats and holy places. She owns a small house of two rooms, and has been living in it with her family for over twenty years.

Surriya is a very talented lady and is an expert in her work. She sells embroided and colored shawls to her customers. Her selection of shawls attracts her customers to her business. Multan is famous for its "saint places". To maintain the legacy, women wear shawls to cover their heads as a sign of respect and men also wear scarves on their heads.

With the loan, Surriya will buy the shawls in bulk. She is hopeful that she can greatly increase her income which will help her family have a better financial life.

loans.use: To purchase shawls in bulk for resale.

loans.name: Tahira Bibi's Group

texts.en:
Tahira Bibi is doing a great job in helping her husband to fulfill the basic needs of the family. She has a boutique and sells clothes and other embroidered products such as shawls and handkerchiefs at a good profit. She has been doing this work for over six years.

Her business is limited to her community, but she wants to start doing business on a larger scale. For this purpose, she has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). With the loan, she will buy a variety of clothes and embroidered items in bulk, which will help her to introduce her work in different clothes shops and to get good orders from them too.

She is very hopeful about the bright future of her boutique business.

loans.use: To purchase the required items for her boutique business.

loans.name: Nyakabare Bakyara Twimukye Group B, Ntungamo

texts.en:
For a time period of ten years, A. David has been running multipurpose businesses that include agriculture and a grocery store in Kabobo cell in Ntungamo. With good management and customer care skills, these businesses generate him a profit of 85,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis.

With hard work, David looks forward to improving his banana plantation through mulching and spraying the pests that are currently disorganizing his crops. This will definitely give his ventures improved conditions for some time.

This loan will contribute to the purchase of pesticides and mulches and also help David to restock his grocery store with more goods that include beans and groundnuts (peanuts).

David’s future plan is to be able to get enough money out of his business to pay his children’s school fees and also to expand his businesses for more income.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides and mulches for his plantation and stock for his store

loans.name: Parveen Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Parveen Akhtar lives in Multan, the city of shrines and sweetmeats in Pakistan. She is a very supportive woman. Besides carrying out her responsibilities as a housewife and being a good mother, she also supports her husband financially with her domestic sewing business. She fulfills orders from her neighbors to sew clothes. She charges reasonable fees for her sewing, which keeps her customers returning. She has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) which she will invest in her sewing business. The loan will help her buy an electric sewing machine. She thinks that in this way she will be able to fulfill the bigger orders on time.

Note: "Parveen Akhtar is doing her domestic work in this picture and Haleema, another group member, is showing her clothes for her clothing selling business".

loans.use: To purchase an electric sewing machine for her sewing business.

loans.name: Shamsihol

texts.ru: Султонова Шамсихол проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 50 лет. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Двое сыновей в Росии на заработках. Сама Шамсихол имеет среднее образование. Занимается торговлей. Она привозит фрукты с кишлаков и продаёт оптом на рынке. Этим видом бизнеса занимается уже 6 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота, т.к. спрос на ее товар увеличился. Шамсихол хочет закупить больше фруктов для продажи.
texts.en:
Shamsihol Sultanova lives near Shahrituz. She is fifty years old, married with four children. She has two sons currently working in Russia. Shamsihol has a secondary education. She purchases fruits from local villagers and sells wholesale in the market. She has been doing this business for six years. She is asking for a loan to purchase more fruit and increase her sales.

Translated from Russian by Susan Savkov, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
Marivic C. is from the village of Sibaroc, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 36 years old. Marivic is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Marivic owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services to local community members. Marivic is just starting this business.

In 10,000, Marivic joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marivic has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Marivic is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide services. This loan will be Marivic's sixth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our field partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide services.

loans.name: Nyakabare Bakyara Tutungukye Group A, Ntungamo

texts.en:
Hardworking and lively 32-year-old T. Loyce made a decision to start her small boutique business in Kitwe Trading centre in Ntungamo 15 years ago. With the money she had earlier saved doing her tailoring business, she bought her first stock of bales of secondhand clothes. With these, her business began.

Though her business has had its share of ups and downs, Loyce has emerged as a strong and determined woman who has refused to give in to any sort of pressure, knowing she has to protect her main source of income. With this kind of spirit, she has made progress as seen in the 300,000 Ugandan shillings she makes monthly.

Loyce is one lady who likes looking at the future and, as such, she has come up with plans she says are for the expansion of her small secondhand clothes business into wholesale. With this loan, she is hopeful she will be able to see her dream come true.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of used clothing to sell

loans.name: Anastasia

texts.en: Anastasia M. N. is 45 years old, single, and has two boys whom she hopes to give a quality education. Her business is located in a growing estate in Nairobi called Dandora. She owns a restaurant in which she serves the local people. She says the business is profitable and the major challenges that she experiences include debtors not paying as per the agreement and the high prices of soft drinks. She has been in this business for the last two years and has managed to provide employment to two people. She is using her loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more soft drinks to sell to the local people. She hopes to expand her business, install electricity in her premises and in the future, she hopes to diversify her business and establish a big supermarket. She describes herself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To buy more soft drinks for her restaurant.

loans.name: Saeeda's Group

texts.en:
Saeeda lives in the third largest city of Pakistan, named Multan. She runs her boutique business out of her home because the rent of shops is too high in Multan. She has a helper who collects orders for her from different areas of Multan, and she makes the finished products for him to deliver on time. Her timely delivery of orders has given her a good reputation with her customers.

Saeeda wants to expand her business, and for this reason she has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan). She will buy some embroidery materials and unstitched clothes for her boutique and display these to attract more customers.

She is hopeful that this will have a positive impact on her business and her income will increase sufficiently to overcome her family’s financial problems.

loans.use: To purchase the required items for her boutique.

loans.name: Samina Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Samina Parveen fills orders from her neighborhood for her embroidery business to earn an income. She lives in Multan, a city of shrines and sweetmeats in Pakistan. She has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan) for her embroidery business.

She is a very skillful woman and keeps herself up-to-date with the new embroidery fashions. Fortunately, her creativity helps her to make new designs in her mind and try to realize them on the clothes. She says that she is blissful by the grace of God that He has caused her to be born with this talent.

Her customers admire her work and give good orders to her. She works hard to manage the orders on time. More than that, she loves her work because it has given her a good business which continues to improve her financial situation.

With the loan she will buy embroidery materials such as clothes, colored thread and beads in bulk which will help her fulfill larger orders in time.

loans.use: To purchase embroidery materials for her embroidery business.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John O. O. is 27 years old. He is married and has four children aged between two and nine years old. His business is located at Kamukunji in a very busy market in Nairobi. He has a business in which he has been selling pans and other items to the local people. He says that this business is profitable and the main challenges he has are the price or raw materials, and that there are very many people in the area doing the same kind of business as his, hence customers are spoilt for choice. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more scrap metal to make the pans to sell. In the future, he hopes to open other outlets. He describes himself as hardworking, focused and determined.

loans.use: To buy scrap metal to make pots and pans to sell.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en: Michael O. A. is 42 years of age. He is married and has five children ranging between the ages of 8 and 18 years. His business is located in Kamukunji, by a busy highway near a busy market in Nairobi. He has been in this business for the last 15 years. He says that the business is good and the only major challenges are the high prices of raw materials and competition. He is using his loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more scrap metal to make frying pans to sell to the local his customers who include walk ins and repeat customers. In the future, he wants to become a wholesaler. He describes himself as hardworking, focused and ambitious.

loans.use: Scrap metal

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred is a hardworking and focused man who owns a barber shop. He has been running the business for seven years and has two employees. He is married and has four children in school. He works hard to educate his children and provide for the family's basic needs. 

He also rents out residential houses to supplement his family income. He has been an active member of Faulu Kenya in a group called Harvesters S.H Ass. He has previously taken out two loans through the group, which he successfully repaid. He has requested a loan of 45,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase a new shaving and smoothing machine.

loans.use: To purchase a new shaving and smoothing machine

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce M. M. is 34 years old. She is married and has two children, one is age 12 and the other is 11 years old. Her business is located at Kamukunji in a very busy market in Nairobi. She has a business in which she has been selling metal boxes to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is the high prices of raw materials. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more materials to make the boxes to sell. In the future, she hopes to buy a plot and expand her business. She describes herself as hardworking, focused and ambitious.

loans.use: Scrap metal

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 34 year old married man with three children.  Two of his children attend school therefore he has to work hard to educate them.

John was employed at a petrol station before he went into the business of selling tyres.  He now earns more income from the business which has been running for ten years with one employee.  He also does farming to earn extra income.

He has requested a loan of 40,000 KES from Faulu Kenya.  He wants to buy more tyres using the money.  He sees himself importing tyres in ten years.

loans.use: To buy tyres for sale

loans.name: Teresiah

texts.en:
Teresiah M. F. is 21 years old. She is single and does not have any children yet. Her business is located in Kamukunji, in a very busy market in Nairobi. She sells cookers, motor boxes, pans and other items to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenges she has are the high prices of raw materials and the fact that there are very many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers, hence customers are spoiled for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more scrap metal, cookers and cement to make the items she sells. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and provide customer service to fulfill her clients' needs. She describes herself as hardworking, focused and dedicated.

loans.use: Cookers, scrap metal and cement

loans.name: Saleem's Group

texts.en:
Saleem lives in a historic city of Punjab, Pakistan, called Multan. Her husband works in a gas station and she helps him financially by selling bangles. She sells a variety of bangles, such as beaded bangles, steel bangles, glass bangles, etc. She has been doing this work for the last five years.  She makes a good income, particularly on EID (a Muslim occasion that comes after Ramadan). 

She has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute and Kiva partner in Pakistan) to purchase bangles for her bangles-selling business. She is hopeful that her income can be increased by offering variety to her clients.

loans.use: Purchase bangles for reselling

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en:
Teresia A. K. is 27 years old, widowed and has two children who are seven years old and two-and-a-half years old. Her business is located in Kamukunji, in a very business market in Nairobi. She has a business in which she has been selling wheelbarrows, metal boxes, chicken feeders and other items to the local people for the past six years. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that there are very many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers, hence customers are spoiled for choice and high prices of raw materials. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Teresia is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more wheelbarrows to expand her business. In future, she hopes to expand her business and serve more people. She describes herself as hardworking and focused.

loans.use: To purchase wheelbarrows for resale

loans.name: Mutunga

texts.en:
Mutunga M. is 32 years old. He is married and has one child who is five years old. Mutunga's business is located in Kamukunji, in a very busy market in Nairobi. He has a business selling metal boxes and other items to the local people for the past two years. He says that this business is profitable and the only major challenges he has are that there are very many people in the area doing the same kind of business as his, hence customers are spoiled for choice, and high prices of raw materials. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

Mutunga is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more scrap metal to make the metal boxes to sell. In the future, he hopes to open other outlets. He describes himself as hardworking, focused and dedicated.

loans.use: To buy scrap metal to make metal boxes for sale

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen T. is from the village of Nacional, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Carmen is single and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Carmen owns and operates a retail store, selling daily use products, such as food for snacks, shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Carmen has been in business for more than one year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Carmen joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to additional capital for her business. Carmen is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Carmen from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Barack

texts.en:
Barack O. O. is 46 years old. He is married and has five children, whom he hopes to provide a quality education. His business is located in Kamukunji, in a very busy market in Nairobi. He has a business in which he has been selling pans, ovens, cookers and other items to the local people. He says that this business is profitable and the only major challenges he has are that there are very many people in the area doing the same kind of business as his, hence customers are spoiled for choice, and the high prices of raw materials. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

Barack is using his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more scrap metal to make the items that he sells. In future, he hopes to open other outlets. He describes himself as determined and goal-oriented.

loans.use: To buy scrap metal for making items to sell

loans.name: Leonila

texts.en:
Leonila L. is from the village of Lubid, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 64 years old and married. To make a living, Leonila owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling delicacies and candies in the local community. Leonila has been in business for more than 20 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Leonila joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Leonila is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Leonila from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma C. is from the village of Lubid, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 40 years old, married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Gemma owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling delicacies like "tinagaktak" and candies in the local community. Gemma has been in business for more than 18 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Gemma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gemma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Gemma is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which also will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Gemma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion M. is from the village of Anonang, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 37 years old, married and has nine school-aged children. To make a living, Salvacion owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily use products, such as candies, snacks, shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Salvacion has been in business for more than four years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Salvacion joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Salvacion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Salvacion is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Salvacion from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine has been operating her retail shop for more than five years. She is married with twin girls who attend school. Her husband works with the Kenya Ports of Authority, and he contributes to the upbringing of the children. 

With the loan of Kshs 50,000, Josephine would want to buy 50 kg of cooking flour, baking flour, cooking oil, 50 kg of sugar, and soft drinks. Her major challenges are competition and the high cost of transportation. Josephine hopes to open another business of selling secondhand clothes in the future. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to uplift her business and improve her living standards. 

Josephine rents a house with electricity but no piped water, citing school fees, food and clothing as her greatest monthly expenses.

loans.use: To buy cooking flour, baking flour, cooking oil, sugar, and soft drinks for resale

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe BENKADI sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et 4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles polygames à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été bien  remboursés 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  condiments alimentaires (tels la pâte d’arachide avec KADIA S.), de l’habillement, des céréales et de la restauration.
KADIA S. compte acheter avec son  prêt, 5 sacs d’arachide pour la fabrication de la pâte d’arachide.
Elle s’approvisionne  en arachide au grand marché et  dans les villages avoisinants. La pâte d’arachide est vendue au  marché de Hamdallaye et en famille à une clientèle composée de femmes, au comptant et  souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 28.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The members of the BENKADI group are married women who, on average, are 39-years old and have 4 children. They live in polygamous families in HAMDALLAYE, a neighborhood of the city of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is their fifth collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance organization to meet their customers’ needs. Past loans were repaid without incident. The group sells condiments (such as peanut paste by KADIA S.), clothing and cereals, and also provides food services. With her loan, KADIA S. plans to purchase 5 bags of peanuts to make peanut paste. She gets her peanut stocks at the main market and in surrounding villages. The peanut paste is sold for cash or often on credit at the Hamdallaye market and to the families, to a customer base consisting of women. She hopes to achieve an average monthly profit of 28.500 francs CFA, a portion of which to be used for the family’s expenses and the remaining portion to be invested in her commercial activities. Her goal is to increase her sales so as to better serve her clientele.

Translated from French by Nathalie Pelletier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of peanuts

loans.name: Brilliance

texts.en:
Brilliance B. is from the village of Gubaan, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 26 years old and married. To make a living, Brilliance owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily use products, such as sugar, salt, shampoo, soap and toothpaste, in the local community. Brilliance has been in business for more than two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Brilliance joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Brilliance has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Brilliance is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Brilliance from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel N. is 48 years old. He is married and has two children who are 12 and 9 years old. Emmanuel owns a restaurant, which is located by the roadside at Dandora estate in Nairobi. He has been in this business for the past five years and has two employees. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenges he has are financial constraints and that there are very many other people doing the same business as his in the area and so customers are spoiled with choice. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

Emmanuel is using his loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more drinks and food to make and sell to his customers. He hopes to expand his business. He also hopes to build a house on his plot of land and buy a matatu to start a transport business, which will add to his income. He describes himself as very hardworking.

loans.use: To buy drinks, and food to make and sell

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David, 28, is married and has two children. He runs Mama Judy General Shop and his wife assists him in the business. David divides his time to manage his business and his job where he works as a driver. He belongs to Prosper group in Faulu Kenya, whose members guarantee one another's loans. 

David has requested for a loan of Kes 40,000 to add stock of sugar, cooking fat and soap in his shop. He hopes to invest in other businesses so as to increase his income.

loans.use: To buy sugar, cooking fat and soap

loans.name: Jiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les  membres du groupe Jiguisseme sont des femmes,  toutes  mariées,  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans, 3 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles monogames à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur troisième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers en générale tels que les pagnes (avec  MARIAM D.), les fruits et légumes, de la friperie, etc.
MARIAM D. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  12 pièces de pagnes. 
Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso et effectue sa vente au  marché de Hamdallaye et en famille à une clientèle composée de femmes au comptant et  souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30 500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Jiguisseme group are all married women, on average 43 years old with three children, and living for the most part in monogamous families in the Hamdallaye borough of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is the group’s third collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customers’ needs, and the preceding loans have been repaid. The group is active in retail commerce of various articles such as pagnes (colourful West-African clothing fabric, sold by Mariam D.), fruits and vegetables, second-hand clothing, etc. With her loan, Mariam D. wants to buy 12 pagnes. She gets her supplies from the main market in Sikasso, and resells at the Hamdallaye market or through home delivery to women customers, for cash and often for credit. She hopes to reach average monthly earnings of 30,500 FCFA of which part will be used for family expenses and the remainder invested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pagnes

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, 50, is a driver by profession and also does farming. He has four children and some are independent. He is assisted by his wife in farming. 

John was introduced to Ikinye Ria Mbere group in Faulu Kenya with his friend who is also a business man. Being in the group, he can be guaranteed a loan by the group members. He has requested for a loan of Kes 35,000 to buy fertilizer and farm equipment. He plans to invest in dairy cattle farming to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and farm equipment

loans.name: Eustaquia

texts.en:
Eustaquia A. is from the village of Poblacion, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 60 years old, married and has two adult-aged children. To make a living, Eustaquia owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling delicacies like fried peanuts, fried bananas and candies in the local community. Eustaquia has been in business for more than 25 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Eustaquia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eustaquia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Eustaquia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the eighth loan taken out by Eustaquia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita A. is from the village of Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 60 years old and married with three adult-aged children. To make a living, Anita owns and operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Anita has been in business for more than three years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Anita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Anita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Anita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en:
Solomon S. is from the village of Kinangay Sur Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, married and has a baby. To make a living, Solomon owns and operates a business planting and harvesting bananas for sale. Solomon has been in business for more than two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Solomon joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Solomon has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Solomon is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Solomon from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe KOTOGNOGONTALA est constitué de 6 femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, 3 enfants et vivant dans des familles polygames à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’habits  pour enfants (avec HAOUA B.), de céréales, de condiments alimentaires,  du bois de chauffe etc.
HAOUA B. compte acheter avec son  prêt, 10 douzaines d’habits pour enfants.  Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso auprès des grossistes. Les habits sont vendus au  marché de Hamdallaye et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 39.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et d’entreprendre des voyages à l’extérieur.
texts.en:
The group KOTOGNOGONTALA consists of six married women, on average 40 years old with three children, and living in polygamous families in the Hamdallaye borough of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is the group’s fifth collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customers’ needs, and the preceding loans have been repaid. This group of women is active in the retail commerce of children’s clothing (as with Haoua B.), grain cereals, food condiments, firewood, etc. With her loan, Haoua B. wants to buy 10 dozen sets of clothing for children. She gets her supplies from wholesalers at the main market in Sikasso. She resells the clothes at the Hamdallaye market and through home delivery to men and women customers, for cash and often for credit. She hopes to reach average monthly earnings of 39,500 FCFA of which part will be used for family expenses and the remainder invested in the commercial activities. Her ambition is to increase her turnover to improve customer satisfaction, and undertake foreign trips.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy children's clothing

loans.name: Leoniza

texts.en:
Leoniza C. is from the city of Gango Ozamz City. She is 44 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Leoniza owns and operates a general store, where she sells a variety of different products, such as food for snacks, cooking oil, sugar, salt, noodles, etc., in the local community. Leoniza has been in business for more than two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Leoniza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leoniza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Leoniza is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 11th loan taken out by Leoniza from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is 24 years old and married with three children. She sells milk to earn a living, while her husband is a driver. She has five years' experience in the business. She also does farming to earn extra income. 

Susan joined a group in Faulu Kenya so that she could access financial resources easily. She has requested a loan of Kes 70,000 to expand her business. Susan hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe SABALI sont des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans, et  en moyenne  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce  des articles divers tels que les  savons (avec SITAN M.), les condiments alimentaires,  les habits pour enfants, les fruits et légumes etc.
SITAN M. compte acheter avec son  prêt  10 cartons de savon auprès des grossistes du grand marché de Sikasso.
Elle vend sa marchandise au  marché de Hamdallaye et en famille à une clientèle composée de femmes au comptant et  souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 29.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et d’entreprendre des voyages à l’extérieur.
texts.en:
The members of the SABALI group are married women, on average 42 years old with four children, and living for the most part in polygamous families in the Hamdallaye borough of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is the group’s first collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customers’ needs. This group of women is active in the retail commerce of various articles such as soap (as with Sitan M.), food condiments, children’s clothing, fruits and vegetables, etc. With her loan, Sitan M. wants to buy 10 cartons of soap from wholesalers at the main market in Sikasso. She sells her products at the Hamdallaye market and through home delivery to women customers, for cash and often for credit. She hopes to reach average monthly earnings of 29,500 FCFA of which part will be used for family expenses and the remainder invested in the commercial activities. Her ambition is to increase her turnover to improve customer satisfaction, and undertake foreign trips.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy soap

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe SABOUGNOUMA  sont  tous des femmes mariées  avec  en moyenne  41 ans,  2 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles monogames à HAMDALLAYE un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de condiments alimentaires, des parures (tels les colliers pour la ceinture appelé “BAYA” utilisé par les femmes, avec  WANA C.),  de céréales, du bois de chauffe etc.
WANA C. compte acheter avec son  prêt  15 colis de parures auprès des fabricants  et grossistes au grand marché de Sikasso
Les parures sont vendus au  marché de Hamdallaye et en famille à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes au comptant et rarement à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 29 500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Sabougnouma group are all married women with a median age of 41 and two children. The majority of them live in monogamous families in Hamdallaye, one of the quarters in the village of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali). They are on their fifth loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to meet their clients' needs. Their past loans have been repaid in full. This group of women sells food condiments, jeweled items (belts called "Baya" used by the women, primarily Wana C.), grains, firewood, etc. With her loan, Wana C. counts on purchasing 15 sets of jewels from the manufacturers and the wholesale distributors at the grand market of Sikasso. The jewelry is sold at the Hamdallaye market and to families, to a clientele composed primarily of women. Sales are done in cash and on credit. She foresees making a monthly profit of 29,500 FCFA, a part of which will be used for her family's needs while the rest will be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of jewelery sets

loans.name: Kholbegim

texts.ru: Хайдарова Холбегим проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 53 года. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Муж, на заработках в России. Сама Холбегим имеет среднее образование. Более 5 лет занимается торговлей. Она продает фрукты на рынке. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
H. Kholbegim lives in the Shahrituz region. She's fifty-three years old, married and has five children. Her husband works in Russia. She has a high school education and has for over five years sold fruit on the market. She's asking for a loan to increase her goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Vergeleta

texts.en:
This is Vergeleta M., 57, a resident of Dasmariñas, Philippines. She is married to Jovencio M. and is the mother of three children, all of whom are already working and are settled down with their own families. By the grace of God, Vergeleta managed to support her children's schooling until they were able to graduate and work. This is a dream for most poor Filipino parents like Vergeleta, as she believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Vergeleta operates a variety store and a rug-making business. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which offers groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go for to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Vergeleta earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling at retail rates. Vergeleta’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy higher quantities of products, like groceries, toiletries and beverages, in order to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  
Vergeleta dreams that her family can be financially stable soon. She also hopes that the business will continue to grow and be successful.

loans.use: To buy higher quantities of products in order to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Najma's Group

texts.en:
Najma and her family live in Multan, Pakistan. Najma's husband is very talented and creative in his work. He is involved in the business of making and selling bangle bracelets. He learned this art from his uncle because he worked for his uncle for several years. He started his own business five years ago. Now he sells the bangles to the neighboring areas and in the bangle shops as well. He takes orders from big jewelry shops and delivers the finished goods on time. 

Najma's husband wants to improve his business by adding more variety to his stock. Therefore, Najma has applied for a loan from Asasah (microfinance institute in Pakistan) for her husband so that he can purchase materials such as plastic, beads and glass in bulk in order to make a variety of bangles and expand the business.

loans.use: Purchase material for making bangles

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe SABOUGNOUMAN sont des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans, 3 enfants et  vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à MANCOURANI un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur cinquième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de produits alimentaires en générale tels que les poissons (avec  NAMINATA T.), le beignet, l’atiéké, etc
NAMINATA T. compte acheter avec son  prêt,  10 cartons de poissons de mer. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso .
Les poissons sont vendus au  marché de MANCOURANI et en famille à une clientèle composée de femmes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 32.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  dans les dépenses de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group SABOUGNOUMAN are married women averaging 38 years of age and three children each living for the most part in polygamous families in MANCOURANI, one of the districts of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The women are on their fifth collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers.  The past loans have been repaid.  This group of women does commerce in foods in general, such as fish (as with Ms. NAMINATA T.), beignets, atiéké (cassava couscous), etc. NAMINATA T. intends to use her loan to buy ten boxes of ocean fish.  She gets her supplies at the big market of Sikasso.  The fish are sold at the MANCOURANI market and as a family.  Accepting cash and often credit, she sells to a customer base composed of women.  She envisions making an average monthly profit of 32,500 francs CFA.  Part of the profit will be used for family expenses, and the other part will be invested in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fish

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married with four daughters who all attend school. She has been operating her tailoring business for five years with the help of her spouse who is employed as a tailor. With the Ksh 20,000 loan, she wants to buy materials of different designs to suit her clients' needs. She earns her other source of income from her husband's salary.

Elizabeth sells to her neighbors and passersby from home. She mentioned seasonality as her major challenge. She hopes to have her own plot of land in the future; she currently rents a house with electricity but no piped water. Elizabeth decided to join Yehu because of the accessibility to sustainable services to improve her living standards. She cites food and electricity as her greatest monthly expenses.

loans.use: To buy different kinds of cloth materials

loans.name: Demba

texts.fr: Monsieur Demba D. est reporter, photographe et cameraman depuis longtemps. Il est marié et est âgé de 43 ans. Il compte sur ce business pour gérer sa famille et est trés connu dans sa ville où il compte de nombreux clients. Il sollicitait un prêt de 150 000 FCFA pour continuer des travaux de construction de bâtiment entamés, il y'a longtemps.
texts.en:
Mister Demba D. has been a reporter, photographer and cameraman for a long time. He is married and 43 years old. He relies on this business activity to support his family and is well known in his town where he has many customers. He has requested a loan of 150,000 CFA francs to continue construction work launched long ago.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction work

loans.name: Jumagul

texts.ru: Тураева Жумагуль проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 47 лет. Замужем, имеет одного ребенка. Муж вместе с сыном на заработках в России. Сама Жумагуль занимается торговлей. Она в основном продает фрукты, которые привозит с других районов. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Jumagul T. lives in the Shahrituz region. She's forty-seven years old, married and has one son, who, together with her husband, works in Russia. Jumagul sells fruit, which she imports from other regions, on the market. She's requesting a loan to increase her goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en: Christopher K. W. provides computer services. He also buys old computers, which he repairs and sells to the local people. He has been in this kind of business for the last four years and he says that the business is profitable and the only major challenge is that there are so many people doing the same kind of business as his. So customers are spoiled by the choice. He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to purchase old computers, repair them and sell to the local people. He plans to grow his business by moving to the ground floor of a busy building where he will stock all computer accessories and later own a computer showroom. He hails from Nairobi and his business is located at the Central Business District of Nairobi. Christopher is married and hasa three-month-old daughter. He describes himself as very hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase old computers.

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra N. lives with her husband and children in Multan, which is famous for its tombs, saints and history.
Her husband is a cobbler and started his independent work 10 years ago. He makes shoes specifically for gents. He takes orders from different factories and shoes shops and delivers them in time to make an income. 
 
Azra herself is a very talented lady; she operates a business selling clothes. She has contacts with different boutiques. She takes orders from the neighboring areas and completes their orders by purchasing from the boutiques. She also travels outside of the city to buy clothes, specifically to Faisalabad (famous for its textiles) and Lahore (famous for its new designs & fashion). 

Azra has applied for a loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan)  to invest money in her husband’s shoe-making business. He will purchase materials such as leather, nails and polish, which he needs to make shoes. The stock in bulk will enable him to finish bigger orders on time. Azra is hopeful that this investment in her husband’s business will enable her family to make their financial life better.

loans.use: To purchase required items for shoe making business

loans.name: Faustin

texts.en:
Faustin is 30 years and married.  Faustin is commonly known in the business for selling a variety of goods in his shop.  Those goods include mainly cosmetic goods, cooking oil, sugar etc.  Faustin is very proud of his business and this is his fifth successful year.  His shop is open from 6 am until 8 pm every day.

Faustin is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business by purchasing a large quantity of foodstuffs.  With this additional business of foodstuffs, Faustin hopes to earn more profits, which in turn will allow him to keep expanding his capital for better financial stability in the future.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of foodstuffs

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is 32 years old and a father of four.  He has been doing carpentry for four years in his O. Quality Furniture shop.
