Una de las actividades de la señora Nilda es la elaboración de comestibles para vender. Ella elabora sus comestibles y los traslada hasta el mercado donde hay mucha concurrencia de gente para vender. Su actividad es muy sacrificado ya que se levanta muy temprano para trabajar y trasladarse en bus hasta el mercado, pero su deseo es la sacar a sus hijos de la mejor manera ayudando a su marido quien es jornalero.

Agradece por la ayuda crediticia ya que facilita su trabajo, y lo invertirá en la compra de carne, condimentos, harinas, pastas, y otros ingredientes.
texts.en:
The San Cayetano committee was formed by a group of friends and works with hope for the goals of each. The members formed a group that is very united and capable of accomplishing activities together that strengthen their unity. One of them is Mrs. Nilda, who does many things within the Committee with the help of her fellow members. One of these things is preparing food for sale. She makes her dishes and transports them to the market where there are many people to sell to. Her job takes sacrifice, as she must get up very early to work and take the bus to market, but she wants the best for her children and for her husband, who is a day laborer. She is thankful for the loan, as it will help her work, and she will use it to buy meat, seasonings, flour, pastries, and other ingredients.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Powell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy materials for making food: meat, vegetables, seasonings, oils, in addition to drinks, cans, disposable containers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To extend her farming land, purchase weedkiller and fertilizer

loans.name: Luka

texts.en: Luka A. M. is forty-three years old, married, and has seven children aged between 2 & 18 years old. His business is located in a residential area in Kakamega, in the western region of Kenya. It is well known as the sugar belt region for its production of sugarcane. For the last twelve years, he has been selling items such as rice, flour, oil, detergents, and soft drinks, among others, to the local people. He says that this business is profitable, and his major challenge is debtors not paying as per their agreements. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of KES 20,000 to buy more general items to expand his business. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future, and to give his children a quality education. He describes himself as very hardworking, honest and humble.

loans.use: to buy more general items to expand his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expanding his arable lands and buying some manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer, seed and labor

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph L. S., 44 years old, is married to a farmer and they have four children aged between 3 and 10. His business is located in a residential area near a busy road in Kakamega, in the western region of Kenya well known as the sugar belt region for its production of sugarcane. Joseph has been selling items such as rice, flour, oil, detergents, soft drinks and others for the last three years to the local people. He says that this business is profitable. The major challenge he has is high prices for the items he sells, making them unaffordable to some local people. However, he works very hard to keep his business going well. He is using his loan of KES 40,000 to buy more general items to expand his business. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He hopes to give his children quality education. He describes himself as very hardworking, honest and humble.

loans.use: to buy cooking fat, sugar and soft drinks

loans.name: Christians Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Victoria describes herself as a hard-working woman. She is 56 years old and she is the leader of the 'Christians' borrower group. Victoria is a petty trader who has been selling fresh yams for the past 8 years. She also engages in farming as her second business to make extra income. She is excited to be taking out this loan, which she will use to purchase 100 yams. She dreams of being able to expand her market.  

Victoria is married to a farmer but does not have any children. She hopes to mobilize more savings to buy a container shop to sell her yams out of.

The other members of Victoria’s group are mostly farmers and as the leader she ensures regular meeting attendance and repayment of loan installments.

loans.use: To purchase 100 fresh yams

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer to plant more acres

loans.name: Nuevo Amanecer Group

texts.es:
El comité “Nuevo Amanecer” se formó con la unión varias vecinas de la ciudad de Villa Elisa. 
 Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas, como la preparación de comidas rápidas, de bijouterie y otros. 
Con el fin de ayudar a su familia la señora Lilian realiza trabajos de artesanía como la fabricación pulseras, collares, aros, carteras, bordados en carteras zapatillas y otros.
Ella fabrica sus mercaderías de acuerdo a los pedidos que recibe de sus clientes.
Sus trabajos son muy admirados ya son hechas de manera muy delicada y con muy buenas terminaciones, y en varios modelos y colores.
texts.en:
The "Nuevo Amanecer" committee was formed by various neighbors in the city of Villa Elisa. All the members of the committee undertake independent crafts, as well as sales, in areas such as: the preparation of quick foods, jewelry, and others. With the goal of helping her family, Mrs. L. creates bracelets, necklaces, earrings, wallets, and embroiders wallets, cloth shoes, and others. She makes her wares according to orders from customers. Her works are very admired, as they are made with care and with good results in a variety of styles and colors.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Powell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials for jewelry and tailoring, like special thread, plastic decorations, etc.

loans.name: Muviti

texts.en: Muviti K. K., 32, is married to a businessman and they have two children, 6 and 10 years old. Her business is located in a busy market in Mwingi that has a lot of goat selling activities taking place. She is, however, served by the Thika branch of SMEP. She has been in this business for the last three years. She says that the business is profitable and the only major challenge she faces is the means to transport the goats to the market. However, she works very hard to keep her business going well. She is using her loan of Kes 10,000 to buy more goats to sell. In the future, she hopes to give her children quality education, build a family house and create employment for people when her business expands. She describes herself as very hardworking, humble and patient.

loans.use: to buy goats

loans.name: Fulvia Beatríz

texts.es:
La Sra Fulvia Beatriz Benitez D. Leguizamon tiene 41 años D. edad, es casada, tiene 2 hijos, ambos mayores que cuentan con sus respectivos ingresos.
DesD. hace 5 años atrás empezó con el negocio D. venta D. artículos D. primera necesidad, luego fue ampliando el rubro comercializando también bebidas y por ultimo con la adquisición D. una fotocopiadora realiza fotocopias para los colegios D. sus alrededores. 
Con el crédito, la cliente aumentará su stock D. mercaderías esperando vender a mas clientes, ella invertra en la compra D. productos D. limpieza en general, panificados, embutidos, articulos D. libreria.
La Sra Fulvia agradece por el apoyo brindado y considera el préstamo como una oportunidad para el desarrollo D. su micro empresa.
texts.en:
Fulvia Beatriz Benitez D. Leguizamon is 41, married, and has 2 children, both of whom are grown and have their own income. Five years ago she started her business selling basic necessities, and later she expanded to sell drinks as well, and finally she acquired a photocopier and she now also makes photocopies for the surrounding schools. With this loan, she will expand her stock of merchandise in the hopes of selling to more customers. She will invest in the purchase of general cleaning products, baked goods, sausages and paper supplies. Fulvia is grateful for the support offered, and considers this loan to be an opportunity for the development of her micro enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: the purchase of general cleaning products, baked goods, sausages and paper supplies

loans.name: C4576 Indatwa Group

texts.en:
Chantal is 37 years old and married with two children, ages 1 and 3 years old. Chantal is the president of a group called INDATWA and this group owns a small grocery where they sell a variety of goods. This group has been in business for a long time. The hours of their business are from 6 am to 7 pm every day.

Chantal and her team are requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to expand the grocery by purchasing a large quantity of goods. With these additional goods, the group will satisfy the demands of the customers. They will earn a lot of money which will be used for reinvestment and to improve the lifestyle of their families.

loans.use: To buy additional goods to sell

loans.name: Gertrudes

texts.en:
Gertrudes G. is a married woman who lives in Martinez Compund, Brgy. Pugalo, Alcoy, Cebu. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures. She operates a general store , she buys and sells recycled materials and also has a Vidoeke businesses.  Her husband Basilio G., who is 62 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living.  He also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have 9 children who are between 2 to  25 years old. 

Gertrudes  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 6 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gertrudes  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,500 - uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 7th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 which she intends to use in purchasing necessary commodities for her general store while the rest can serve as a capital in her scrap business so that she could continue to save up for the future renovation of their house and to send their children to school . 

Gertrudes G. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To be used for additional working capital

loans.name: Lucía Gervacia

texts.es:
Lucia Gervasia R. D. Gimenez tiene 51 años D. edad, es casada y  tiene 3 hijos. 
DesD. hace 2 años atrás empezó con el negocio D. Venta D. varios artículos como ropas, calzados, y accesorios D. librería. 
A los un año D. haber empezado su micro comercio construyo un local frente a su casa y se encuentra instalada en dicho local actualmente. 
El crédito obtenido será invertido en la compra D. mercaderías(articulos D. libreria, calzados, merceria en general y otros), con lo que espera aumentar su nivel D. ventas con un mejor y mas variado stock D. mercaderías; Lucia agradece por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Lucia Gervasia R. D. Gimenez is 51, married and has 3 children. Two years ago she started her business selling various articles such as clothing, footwear and paper items. After a year of starting her micro business she built an area in the front of her house and that is where the business is currently located. The loan will be invested in the purchase of merchandise (paper items, footwear, general items and others), with which she hopes to increase her level of sales with a better and more varied stock of merchandise. Lucia is grateful for the support offered.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: the acquisition of merchandise such as paper items and other items, such as shoes, t-shirts and seasonal clothing

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
Alejandra A. is a 48-year old, married, and supports her family by operating 3 business ventures. She is a Avon Franchise Dealer,  a Natasha Dealer and has a Fuller Life businesses.  She lives in , Brgy. Guiwang, Alcoy, Cebu. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her Avon Franchise Dealer , Natasha Dealer and Fuller Life businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average income of Php10,000. 

Alejandra is now borrowing PHP 18,000 so that she could directly purchase Avon products.  This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon.  Her previous loan of Php16,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Alejandra aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for her three businesses

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia is married with five children, who all attend school. She resides in and owns a four room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include utility bills and feeding the family.

Sylvia used to sell snacks but a few months ago changed her business enterprise. She owns a store in Kyebando selling charcoal wholesale. Sylvia works six days a week. She doesn’t incur any transportation costs as she buys her charcoal from delivery vans which get the charcoal from villages. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She hopes to start going to villages for charcoal. Sylvia joined MCDT because she wanted to boost her business by getting additional capital.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Teopista

texts.en:
Teopista is widowed with four children, who all attend school. She also takes care of additional family members. She resides in and owns a four room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include utility bills and food.

Teopista owns a stall in Ntinda market, where she sells bananas which she buys from the Masaka district. She uses public transportation to get and transport the bananas. She has been in this business for sixteen years. She also owns a piggery farm at her home. Teopista works six days a week. Her business challenges include transportation and seasonality. Teopista wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She joined MCDT because she wanted timely loans.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Adiyisem Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Petty trading like the sale of groceries is widespread in Ghana because it is easy to start up the business. It usually begins with table-top selling and then grows to become a kiosk and eventually becomes a supermarket. Isheitu is one of such entrepreneurs; she has been trading in groceries like biscuits, bottled water, candies, canned foods, rice, cooking oil, toiletries, etc. for the past 6 years. She is hoping that, one day, she will be able to rent a bigger shop to expand her business. 

Isheitu is excited to be taking the loan which she plans to invest in purchasing groceries in bulk to serve her customers. She anticipates increasing her profit level and also expanding her market. 

Isheitu is married to a farmer and they have two children, ages 7 and 13. She describes herself as an excellent group leader of 'Adiyisem' Borrower Group, made up of 6 members. As the leader of the group, she ensures regular meeting attendance and repayment of loan installments.

loans.use: To purchase groceries in bulk

loans.name: Nshumi_Twimukye Group, Bushenyi

texts.en:
29-year-old, happily married A. Syson operates her clothing sells business making 700,000 shillings monthly. With this, this delightful woman has taken all her family responsibilities in her stride. All her three kids are in school. She has done all this under the umbrella of her boutique business which she has operated for the last seven years in Kizinda, Bushenyi.

Syson’s dream of owning this clothing sells business materialized on the back of the accumulation of her small group savings money. She started off as a retailer but later decided to open up a boutique instead. With this loan, she reckons she will be in a strong financial position to purchase more clothes for her boutique, clothes that she will later resell.

Syson has a dream of increasing her business stock as well as having all her children put in good schools till they complete studies. She sees an increase in her business capital and meeting her family's needs.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is widowed with three children, who all attend school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She resides in and rents a two room house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.

Norah owns a restaurant in Kyebando market selling chips, chaps and liver. She has been in this business for six years. Her business challenge is the transportation of Irish potatoes from Kalerwe market to her place of work in Kyebando. Norah wants to use this loan to buy Irish potatoes, cooking oil and liver. Norah joined MCDT because she wanted additional capital.

loans.use: to buy Irish potatoes, cooking oil and liver

loans.name: Tophas

texts.en:
47-year-old M. Tophas is happily married and the mother of seven. Her business preoccupation is a retail shop which she has operated for the last twenty years. That time span speaks volumes about her hard work, efficiency and good planning. To bring this business into existence, she had to use her little savings from her erstwhile retail shop. Her side source of income is selling bananas.

In a week, Tophas’ profits sum up to 40,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to purchase more retail merchandise for her retail shop: items like sugar, soap, cups, cutlery, sandals and basins.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items like sugar, soap, cups and cutlery, sandals and basins

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is 23 years old and married with one child who is 2 and a half years old. Sarah makes a living by selling a variety of goods in her shop. Her shop is open from 6 am to 6 pm every day. Although Sarah has owned her shop for a long time, her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully. To end this, Sarah is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company. If she gets this loan, Sarah will purchase additional goods, mainly foodstuffs like rice, sugar, etc. With these additional goods, Sarah will hopefully earn more profit which will allow her to keep reinvesting for better financial stability.

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods, mainly foodstuffs, to sell

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
40-year-old A. Alex is, without a shadow of a doubt, a go-getter. The attitude of being proactive in whatever you do in life is one he came to terms with after he saw his childhood friends fail in their endeavors to effectively manage their businesses. What occurred to him was the thought that without effective planning and a sense of diligence and involvement, one’s enterprise is bound to go up in smoke.

At length, Alex got his own plans into gear, setting up, against all odds, his own retail shop and later a video hall in Kizinda, Bushenyi. His hardwork ethic has been his stock in trade. He also now has his small rental apartments from where he ekes out side profits. In a week, he makes profits totaling up to 35,000 shillings.

With this loan, Alex wants to start the construction of a new video hall.

loans.use: To construct a new video hall

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en: Thomas was born in 1986 and still lives with his parents. After changing his business, Thomas now has a business selling soft drinks such as: milk, water and Fanta, as well as cakes and bread. His business is organized and well known in the region. Thomas employs one person in his business as a helper. This is his fifth year of success as an entrepreneur and he has one year of experience in this business. Currently, the hours of his daily activities are from 7 in the morning to 9 in the evening except on Saturday. Thomas is requesting a second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand his business by purchasing more soft drinks. Hopefully Thomas will be able to be more efficient and effective in his business. With the extra money, Thomas wishes to buy a machine which can keep the milk well.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Winnie

texts.en:
Winnie is widowed with six children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of her late brothers children.  

She owns a retail shop in Mulago selling all types of merchandise. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, boxes of mineral water, boxes of Safi (a skin tonic), cartons of salt and loaves of bread. Winnie has been in this business for six years.  She buys this merchandise from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala. She uses public transport to and from shopping and goes for shopping once a week.   She works six days a week. 

Winnie wants to see her business grow bigger and start selling on a wholesale basis only and also to buy a plot of land. She joined MCDT because of the low interest charged.  She rents and resides in a two-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of Safi, mineral warer and loaves of bread.

loans.name: Fred

texts.en:
“Rise up to the occasion” – he truly has been a testament to that. This is the simple business story of 41-year-old M. Fred, an enterprising produce-sales businessman operating in Nyamadane in Bushenyi.

Fred is a happily married man with ten children. As proof of the fact that he has what it takes to take care of all of them, he says he has seen all of them through school, the last born having recently finished his “A-levels” (high school advanced-level exams). Calling into question why he has such a big number of children is something which is frowned upon, especially in a rural setting where people believe in having many children, notwithstanding their financial status.

It’s a modest six-year-old business, but it has enabled Fred to make ends meet to a certain degree on weekly profits of 60,000 shillings. Barring the achievements he has registered, he is still behind schedule in many of his other set objectives. It’s for this reason that he wants this loan. He figures he will be able to purchase in bulk more crops like maize, beans, groundnuts (peanuts) and peas that he hopes to resell.

loans.use: To purchase in bulk crops like maize, beans, groundnuts, etc.

loans.name: Odette

texts.en:
Odette is 51 years old and married with seven children who are between 5 and 17 years old. Odette is well known in her business selling mainly women's clothes. She has been in this business for about four years. The hours of her business are from 7 am to 6 pm every day.

Odette is now requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company to purchase additional mixed styles of all sizes. With this additional stock, Odette will hopefully earn more profit which will allow her to reinvest and save for her future. In addition, Odette will improve living conditions for her children and try to create many sources of income for the people of her community.

loans.use: To buy different styles of clothes to sell

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice is 40 years old and married with two children.  She earns her income from her retail shop which has been running for six years.  In addition, she rents out houses. Since she joined Faulu Kenya in a group called Delta, she has learned how to manage her finances by saving her money with the group.  She has requested a loan of 50,000 KES to add to her stock of sugar, cooking fat, sweets and maize flour. She hopes to build apartments in the future.

loans.use: To buy sugar, cooking fat, sweets and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Berna

texts.en:
Berna is widowed with five children. Two of her children died and the rest are in school.  She also takes care of her late brother’s son. 

She owns a shop in Kamwokya where she sells children's clothes, both new and old.  She has been in this business for five years.  

Berna wants to use this loan to buy more bales of secondhand and new baby’s clothes.  She works seven days a week.  Her business challenges are seasonality and defaulters.  

She would like to be able to build rental rooms in the available space, and also to see her business grow bigger. She would like to import the clothes directly. She joined MCDT because of the low interest rate charged.  

She owns and resides in a three-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses include food, school fees and utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more bales of secondhand and new clothes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more fish.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, pepper and oil

loans.name: Mariuxi Mercedes

texts.es:
Mariuxi de 32 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín de Guayaquil, su casa es de caña y tiene tres hijos. Ella vende comida por la ventana de su casa, afuera tiene una mesa para los clientes que quieren comer allí (observen la foto). 

Antes de vender comida en su casa, ella trabajaba en un puesto de la esquina de su casa de comida pero al ver que era bueno sus ingresos decidió trabajar desde su casa haciendo la comida, poco a poco compro sillas y mesas plásticas para mas comodidad de sus clientes. Trabaja desde las 10h00 hasta las 19h00pm todos los días. 

Para tener mas víveres para cocinar ella quiere comprar con el préstamo carnes, arroz y bebidas para su negocio de venta de comida. En el futuro quiere tener muchos mas clientes y que sus hijos continúen estudiando.
texts.en:
32-year-old Mriuxi lives in a house made of reeds in the settlement el Fortín in the outskirts of Guayaquil. She has three children. She sells food from the window of her house. Outside she has a table for her customers that want to eat there (see the photo). Before selling food from her home, she worked at a food stand on the corner by her house, but seeing that the income was good, she decided to work from home making the food. Little by little she bought the plastic tables and chairs for her customers. She works from 10am to 7pm every day. In order to increase her supplies of food, she wants to use the loan to buy meat, rice and drinks for her food-selling business. In the future she wants to have a lot more customers and her children to continue studying.

Translated from Spanish by Jacqueline Demeranville, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy drinks, meat and rice

loans.name: God Is In Control Group

texts.en:
James T., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called God Is In Control. 

He is 25 years old and single.  James was only able to attend school through 9th grade due to lack of financial support.  

For 4 years, he has been operating a motorcycle transport business in Harbel Firestone, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

He plans to use his 6,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this group loan to buy a motorcycle.

James deecribes himself as kind and easy-going. His dream is to expand his business and  buy more motorcycles.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Doris' picture is inset at lower right because she was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Lift The People Group

texts.en:
Mariama K., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Lift the people. She is 41 years old, married and has two children who range from 14 to 20 years old. She also cares for two siblings.

She was only able to attend school through 10th grade due to lack of financial support. 

For 15 years, she has been operating a beauty salon in Peter Town, Harbel, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 7,000 LRD portion of this 25,000 LRD group loan to buy more hair dressing materials like shampoo, hair rollers, and a hair dryer, etc. She describes herself as a kind woman.

Her goal is to improve her business and continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Musa is inset at lower right because he was absent during disbursal.

loans.use: To buy more hair dressing materials like shampoo, hair rollers and a hair dryer, etc.

loans.name: Eddy

texts.es: Eddy tiene 29 años por lo que su actividad es la reparación de bicicletas. Hace más de 7 años que tiene este negocio, el inicio este negocio solamente con la reparación de bicicletas con el paso del tiempo y con los financiamientos que han sido de gran ayuda para que el iniciara este negocio que es su principal fuente de ingresos. El financiamiento que está solicitando es para la compra de materia prima como es llantas, pedales, asientos, cadenas, destornilladores entre otras cosas. Sueña con ampliar su negocio y también brindar el alquiler de servicio de triciclo.
texts.en:
Eddy, 29, is a bicycle repairman. He’s been in this business for 7 years. He started out just repairing bicycles. The passage of time and financing has been of great help to his starting the business which is now his main source of income. He will use the requested funds to buy raw materials like: pedals, tires, seats, chains, screwdrivers, among others. He dreams with expanding his business and also to offer three-wheel cycle rental services.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bicycle replacement parts.

loans.name: Twetungure Women, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
Hardworking, purposeful, and humorous, 40-year-old B. Edith, like many other single women in Uganda, is another example of the fact that a determined woman can live her life without the support of a man when a marriage goes wrong.

For eight years, Edith has successfully operated her bookshop business in Ishaka, Bushenyi, albeit with many challenges. She has used her courage and conviction to prevail in narrow circumstances like the aforementioned. She has used earnings from her business to give her one, 28-year-old son a good education.

Edith started off this business with some money that her late husband had as savings. In a week, her business generates her profits totaling up to 50,000 shillings and, with this loan, she wants to purchase a binding machine, binding materials, books and other forms of stationery.

loans.use: To purchase a binding machine, binding materials, books, and other forms of stationery

loans.name: Ruben De Los Angeles

texts.es: Rubén De Los Ángeles tiene 36 años, su actividad económica es brindar el servicio de contratista. Hace más de 2 años que tiene este negocio pues inicio como estudiante con el paso de tiempo es que ha fue aprendiendo este negocio que para él lo vio como una fuente de ingreso para un futuro y fue así como decide ofrecer este servicio a quienes lo necesitan, el se siente muy afortunado por la oportunidad que le brindan pues para el muy importante para comprar herramientas como soldador, pulidora, brocas, martillo entre otras cosas. Sueña con terminar de construir su vivienda.
texts.en:
Rubén De Los Ángeles, 36, is a contractor. He has been in this line of work for over two years. He started out as a student but as time went by he learned the business which he recognized as being a good source of income for his future. This is how he decided to offer this service to those who need it. He feels very fortunate for the opportunity he is offered because it’s important for him to be able to buy tools and equipment like welding machines, polishers, drill bits, hammers, etc. He dreams with completing building his house.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy work tools and equipment.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is widowed with seven children and all her children are in school.  She also takes care of her brother’s daughter.  She owns a retail shop in Mulago and sells all types of merchandise, like sugar, salt and soap, and also refreshments like sodas, mineral water and juice. She has been in this business for five years. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and crates of sodas.  She rents her business premises for 50,000 UGX per month.   Margaret works seven days a week.  Her business challenges includes seasonality and transportation of merchandise from Kikuubo to her shop in Mulago. 

She wants to get a permanent business location.  She joined MCDT because she needed additional capital. Margaret rents and resides in a two-room house where the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses include rent, food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to sell

loans.name: One Mind Group

texts.en:
Musu G., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called One Mind. She is 60 years old and married, with nine children who range in age from 17 to 35 years old. Musu cares for six siblings.

Musu was not able to attend school due to poverty. For more than 20 years, she has been selling bitter-boy okra, eggplant and pepper in Harbel Market, outside of Monrovia, Liberia.

She plans to use her 8,000 Liberian Dollars portion of this 40,000 group loan to buy more okra,  eggplant and pepper to sell. Musu describes herself as a kind and humble woman, and she plans to use increased profits resulting from this loan to improve her business and build a shop.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Jenneh K. is inset at the lower left because she was not present during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more okra, eggplant and pepper.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, pepper, beans and oil

loans.name: Yanira Del Carmen

texts.es:
Yanira del Carmen, tiene 35 años de edad, residen en el Municipio de Cacaopera del Departamento de  Morazán, está acompañada y tiene dos hijos de las edades de 8 y 12 años, ella tiene un negocio de ventas de verduras y frutas.
Ella tiene dos años de manejar el negocio, y está ubicado en un lugar de mayor demanda y tránsito de personas de la localidad, atiende su venta de 7:am a 5:pm en la  vida pública, ella es una persona trabajadora, honesta, que con las ganancias de su venta mantiene las necesidades de su familia.
Ella actualmente necesita un préstamo para compra de productos como son: tomates, cebollas, repollos, plátanos y naranjas entre otros con esto ella espera mejor sus ventas, y dar a su clientes variedad de productos que le demandan y por falta de dinero no los puede comprar.
Las aspiraciones de Yanira son crecer su negocio y de ser posible a futuro comprar con sus ahorros  un Vehículo para salir a vender a otros lugares de esa forma, mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia y apoyar a sus hijos con los estudios.
texts.en:
Yanira del Carmen, 35, lives in the municipality of Cacaopera in the Morazán department. She has a partner and 2 sons, aged 8 and 12. She has a business selling vegetables and fruit. She has been running this business for 2 years. It is located in a place with high demand, where many local people pass through. She attends to her store from 7am until 5pm. In the community she is a person who is known to be hardworking and honest. With the earnings from her store, she is able to support the basic needs of the family. She currently needs a loan to buy products such as: tomatoes, onions, cabbage, bananas, oranges, and other items. With this she hopes to increase her sales and give her customers the variety of products that they want but that she was not able to buy due to lack of funds. Yanira's aspirations are to grow her business and possibly in the future buy, with her savings, a vehicle so that she could sell in other places, so as to improve the quality of life of her family and support her children's education.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprar: tomates, cebollas, repollos, plátanos y naranjas.

loans.name: Juan Ramón

texts.es:
El señor Juan Ramón  es un comerciante de 60 años de edad, está casado con la señora Amada Carvallo de Baéz hace 35 años, quien le dio 12 hijos de los cuales son 7 mujeres y 5 varones, ya casi todos están casados o en parejas sólo viven con ellos 3 hijos y la menor tiene 13 años y está en el colegio. 
Viven en casa propia en la ciudad de Villa Elisa  hace 13 años.
Ellos emigraron de la ciudad de Caazapá, donde se dedicaba a los trabajos de agricultura, cría de animales y aves de corral este trabajo lo hacía con toda su familia.
Llegaron a la ciudad y compraron para su propiedad en el distrito de San Antonio, donde habilitó una despensa en donde podía vender todo tipo de mercaderías y productos a granel.
Le gusta mucho el  comercio porque le permite estar en contacto con la gente de su barrio y conocer clientes en los lugares donde se abastece de mercaderías, cuenta que le involucra a sus hijos en el negocio  porque es la mejor manera de independizarse e ir creciendo, es por eso que muchos de sus hijos tienen también su negocio propio.
El crédito que retira es para ellos un gran apoyo porque con ello puede adquirir  mercaderías en mayor cantidad  a menos precios como arroz, azúcar, harina, aceites y otros.
texts.en:
Juan Ramon is a merchant, 60 years old, and has been married to Amada for 35 years. They have 12 children, of whom 7 are female and 5 male. Almost all are married or living with partners now. Just 3 children still live with them; the youngest is 13 and still in school. They have lived in their own home in the city of Villa Elisa for 13 years. The couple emigrated from the city of Caazapa where they had performed agricultural work, while raising livestock and chickens. This was done with all their family. Upon arrival in the city, they purchased property in San Antonio district, and rehabilitated a store where they could sell all types of merchandise and products in bulk. Juan Ramon enjoys commerce because it permits him to be in contact with the people of his barrio and also, to know clients in the areas that supply the merchandise. He says that he includes his children in the business because it is the best way to make them independent and to continue growing. As a result, many of them now have stores of their own. The loan he is taking out will be a great help, allowing him to acquire merchandise in larger quantities at lower prices, including rice, sugar, flour, cooking oil, and other items.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING DRINKS, RICE, SUGAR, MEAT, TEA, AND BULK PRODUCTS TO SELL

loans.name: Jessica Betty

texts.es:
Jessica de 30 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín de Guayaquil, tiene tres hijos y tiene un taller de costura. Hace cinco años atrás como ella no tenia posibilidades de trabajar en una empresa tuvo que aprender a coser. 

Aunque tuvo que esperar cinco años para tener bastante clientela ella continua trabajando, ahora ella trabaja desde muy temprano hasta que terminar de hacer todos los pedidos, su hermana le ayuda en las tarde cosiendo la ropa. 

Para tener mas posibilidades de hacer ropa ella quiere comprar una maquina de coser industrial con el préstamo. Pero en el futuro ella quiere que su taller se convierta en el mas grande del sector por donde vive.
texts.en:
Jessica, age 30, lives in the periurbana district of Fortín in Guayaquil. She has three children, and she has a seamstress shop. Five years ago when she did not have opportunities for work in a company, she had to learn to sew. Even though she had to wait five years to have enough customers, she continued working. Now she works from very early until she finishes with all of the orders. Her sister helps her sew clothes in the afternoon. In order to have more opportunities to make clothes she wants to buy an industrial sewing machine with the loan. In the future she wants her shop to become the largest in the area where she lives.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Industrial sewing machine

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en:
Sauda is married with five children and all her children go to school. She also takes care of her aging father. 

Sauda owns a store from which she sells charcoal to all categories of people on both a retail and a wholesale basis.  She has been in this business for three years.  

She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. She doesn’t incur any transport costs because she takes the bus to and from her place of work. 

Her business challenges includes defaulters and the rainy season because she works from an open place.  She is hoping to go directly to villages for charcoal in the future. 

She decided to work with MCDT because she wanted additional capital.  She rents a two-room house but the family has no access to electricity or piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: G.s. Angeles Group

texts.es: El grupo Solidario Ángeles está conformado por Iveth y Loyda por lo que juntas se dedican a diferentes actividades económicas. Por lo que Iveth realiza la venta de cosméticos ambulante pues la mayoría de sus clientes viven en comarcas muy alejadas y pues ella aprovecha para realizar las visitas en sus viviendas en donde disfruta de ofrecer sus productos pues siempre carga un bolso con ropa interior, pantalones, camisas, vestidos, trajes y cosméticos. Así fue con el paso del tiempo que logro juntarse con Loyda Jesel para realizar un financiamiento para la compra de materia prima para su negocio. Juntas sueñan con ampliar sus negocios.
texts.en:
The Ángeles communal bank is made up of Iveth and Loyda, and they each work in different economic activities. Iveth sells cosmetics as a traveling vendor. Most of her clients live in very remote areas. She always visits them in their house, where she offers them her products—she always brings with her a bag with intimate clothing, pants, blouses, dresses, suits, and cosmetics. Over time she was able to join up with Loyda Jesel to obtain a loan for the products for her business. Together they dream of expanding their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital to purchase merchandise

loans.name: Kyenjojo Bakyara Twekambe, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
Hardworking 40-year-old K. Laila has, over the last four years, been overseeing her growing spare parts business in Kyenjojo town.

With a weekly net profit of 100,000 Ugandan shillings, this married lady has enjoyed the good that has come with running this lucrative business. All her six children are in good schools around Kyenjojo. Consequently, she has made good progress in as far as educating her children is concerned.

Laila’s first step after acquiring this loan is to purchase more stock of car spare parts with an objective of turning her business into one of the biggest in Western Uganda.

Laila belongs to a group of members who hold each other accountable and insure one another in paying back the loan.

She has a dream of being able to import her own vehicles for sale and this will greatly improve her standard of living, to enable her take good care of her six children and three orphans.

loans.use: To purchase car spare parts for resale

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en:
Cissy is married with four children and three of them go to school. The last born is three months old.  She also takes care of her late brother's children. She owns and resides in a four-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.   

Cissy owns a bar in Nabweru in Kawempe Division. Formerly she had restaurant, but changed her business enterprise to a bar four months ago. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and local gin.  She works seven days week. She is hoping to own a fully stocked bar in the future.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of local gin

loans.name: Maritza Bernarda

texts.es: Maritza Bernarda tiene 46 años por lo que no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos, Es una mujer muy responsable ya que tiene 3 hijos a su cargo y los mantiene ella ya que es madre soltera. Su actividad económica es una pulpería, por lo que más de 16 años que se dedica a este negocio a pesar de las dificultades que enfrento como es el poco apoyo que tenia por lo que no tenía el capital suficiente para invertir en todos los productos. Ahora solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de golosinas, café, jugos, pan, galletas y gaseosas.
texts.en:
Maritza Bernarda is 46 years old. This isn’t the first time she has requested a loan. She is a very responsible woman who has 3 children in her care. She provides for them because she is a single mother. Her business is a small grocery store, which she has had for more than 16 years, despite the difficulties she has faced due to the fact that she didn’t have sufficient capital to purchase all of the products she needed. She is now requesting this loan for working capital so she can buy sweets, coffee, juices, bread, cookies, and soft drinks.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital to purchase merchandise

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Danaya est composé de six femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 45 ans et 5 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le chef lieu de commune rurale: Cinzana Gare, dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et de mariage dans le village. 
Les membres du groupe font le commerce de riz, d’arachide, des boites de concentrées de tomates, des boissons locales (le Dolo à base de mil) et des pagnes wax. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Rokia S. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 5 sacs d’arachide en gousses.  Elle se ravitaille en arachide à la foire du village. Avant de revendre son arachide, elle les trie pour avoir les bonnes gousses et les grille dans une marmite avec le feu. Elle les emballe dans des plastiques pour les revendre en détail, au comptant ou à crédit à la foire du village, à domicile et en ambulant dans les villages environnants à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et d’enfants. 
A l’instar des autres femmes du groupe, Madame Rokia S. espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et assurer les soins de santé des enfants.
texts.en:
The group Danaya is composed of six married women mostly in monogamous families.  The women average 45 years of age and five children each.  They all live in the seat of the rural community of Cinzana Gare, in the Ségou region (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through ties of community, kinship, and marriage in the village.  The group members do commerce in rice, peanuts, cans of tomato paste, local beverages (Dodo, made from millet), and wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth). With the goal of increasing their working capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second solidarity loan cycle.  Ms. Rokia S. intends to use her loan for buying five sacks of peanut.  She stocks up on peanuts at the village fair.  Before selling her peanuts, Rokia sorts them to obtain the good ones and then roasts them in a pot over a fire.  She wraps them in plastic for retail sale.  Cash or credit is accepted at the village fair, at the house, and door-to-door in the surrounding villages.  Her customer base is composed of women, men, and children.  Just like the other women in the group, Rokia hopes to make an average monthly profit of 22,000 francs CFA that will be use to reinvest in business and to ensure her children's health care. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying peanuts

loans.name: Fanni Rosa

texts.es:
Fanny Rosa, tiene 41 años, es casada, tiene dos hijos y es natural del Cusco. Ella es cantante de la discoteca la Rustica de la ciudad del Cusco, ella empieza a trabajar a la media noche hasta las tres de la mañana todos los días y ya son más de 10 años que se dedica a esta profesión. Ella empezó su carrera musical en la Orquesta Dilema, Sentimiento Perú, Berbe latino, etc. A parte de ser cantante también se dedica  a la venta de ropa por campaña navideña. Fanny requiere el préstamo para uso personal y para su negocio, el 50% utilizara en el negocio y la otra parte para el tratamiento de su hijo que sufre de glaucoma ceguera avanzada. 
El sueño de la socia Fanny es producir su propio musical discográfico con canciones inéditas y propias de ella. La socia se encuentra agradecida y contenta con los microcréditos pues le ayudan mucho para tener un ahorro para cualquier emergencia de su hijo.
texts.en:
Fanny Rosa is 41 years old. She is married, has two children, and is from Cusco. She is a singer at the “Rustica” dance club in the city of Cusco. She works from midnight until 3:00am everyday and she has been working in this profession for more than 10 years. She began her musical career in Orquesta Dilema, Sentimiento Perú, Berbe Latino, etc. In addition to being a singer, she also sells clothing for the Christmas holidays. Fanny needs the loan for personal use and for her business. She will use 50% in her business and the other half for medical treatment for her son, who suffers from advanced glaucoma. Fanny’s dream is to produce her own music album of her own unpublished songs. She is very grateful for and happy with the micro-loans because they help her to have savings for any emergency that her son might have.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fanny needs the loan for personal use and for her business.

loans.name: Horonya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Horonya est composé de sept femmes mariées majoritairement dans des ménages monogames avec en moyenne 36 ans et 3 enfants. Elles habitent toutes dans le chef lieu de commune rurale : Cinzana Gare, dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de mariage dans le village. 
Les membres du groupe font le commerce de riz, d’arachide, de parures (bracelets et colliers autours du cou et de la ceinture), de fruits sauvages et d’ustensiles en plastiques (seaux et tasses). 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 2ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Bintou M. est beaucoup sollicitée dans la vente des parures traditionnelles dans le village et son environnant surtout en cette période de mariage. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 10 kg de pièces de perles « kononkissè » et un rouleau de fil en nylon au grand marché de Bamako. 
Pour confectionner un collier, elle trie d’abord dans le lot des perles des couleurs de pièces qui peuvent attirer, met le fil à l’aiguille et les entasse une à une au fil selon le goût de sa clientèle. 
Elle les revend à la foire du village, à domicile et en ambulant dans les villages environnants à une clientèle composée exclusivement de femmes généralement au comptant. 
A l’instar des autres femmes du groupe, Madame Bintou M. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 23 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour l’épargne, assurer les denrées de premières nécessités du foyer et les fournitures scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
The group Horonya is composed of seven married women mostly in monogamous households.  The women average 36 years of age and three children each.  They all live in the seat of the rural community of Cinzana Gare, in the region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through ties of kinship and marriage in the village.  They do commerce in rice, peanuts, fine accessories (bracelets, necklaces, and belts), wild fruit, and plastic ware (buckets and tubs).  With the goal of increasing their working capital, the group members decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their second solidarity loan cycle.  Ms. Bintou M. is much in demand for selling fine, traditional accessories in and around the village, especially during this wedding season.  She intends to use her loan for buying 10 kg of kononkissè beads and a spool of nylon string at the big market of Bamako.  To make a necklace, she first sorts the lot for the colored beads that might be attractive.  Then she threads the string through the needle and stacks the beads one by one along the string, according to the tastes of her customers.  She sells the necklaces at the village fair, at home, and by going door-to-door in the surrounding villages.  Generally accepting cash, she sells to a customer base composed exclusively of women.   Just like the other women in the group, Bintou plans on making an average monthly profit of 23,000 francs CFA that will be put into savings and used to ensure household necessities and school supplies for the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying « kononkissè ». beads

loans.name: Marthe

texts.fr:
Jeune femme de 27 ans, evoluant dans le commerce des produits en detail tel que sandales,habits,ustensiles de cuisine ainsi que les produits de beaute.Elle s'approvisionne dans les grands depots de la place et a Kinshasa, sa recette journaliere varie  de 15000 FRS et 25.000 frs.
Tres active et entreprenante dans la gestion de son activite ,orpheline depuis son jeune age elle s'occupe des  ses soeurs
Toujours a l'ecoute des  besoins des ses clients, elle s'applique avec rigueur et a une grande capacite de coordonner ses nombreuses activites et malgres l'inflation , elle tient le coup pour faire croitre son business .A l'avenir elle compte ouvrir un restaurant et pense aussi soutenir ses soeurs pour qu'elles poursuivent des longues etudes
texts.en:
This is a young woman, aged 27, who has had a retail business involving goods such as sandals and kitchen utensils, as well as beauty products.  She gets her supplies at the big local outlets and in Kinshasa.  Her daily receipts vary from 15,000 to 25,000 francs.  She is very active and enterprising in managing her business.  An orphan since she was young, she is taking care of her sisters.  Today, attending to the needs of her customer, she rigorously applies herself with a great ability for coordinating her numerous activities.  And despite inflation, she is hanging in there in order to grow her business.  In the future, she plans on opening a restaurant, and she is also thinking of supporting her sisters, so that they advance far in their education.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her business and starting a restaurant business

loans.name: Sabougnouman Group

texts.fr:
Les huit membres du groupe Sabougnouman sont des femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 43 ans et 6 enfants.  Elles vivent toutes dans le chef lieu de commune rurale : Cinzana Gare, dans la région de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de mariage, de leurs activités génératrices de revenus dans le village et dans les foires fréquentées. 
Les membres du groupe font l’achat et la vente d’arachide, de pomme de terre, du riz, des boîtes de concentrée de tomate (avec Djènèba Konaté), des boissons locales alcoolisées (le Dolo, à base de mil), et des articles de boutique (bonbon, OMO, savon, biscuits, ) 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce afin de faire leurs achats au comptant, elles ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 3ème cycle de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Djènèba Konaté compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 7 cartons de concentrée de tomate contenant chacun 6 boîtes.  
Elle se ravitaille en concentrée de tomate à Koutiala, en gros et les revend en détail, à la foire du village et à domicile, au comptant et parfois à crédit à une clientèle composée généralement de femmes. 
A l’image des autres femmes du groupe, Madame Djènèba Konaté espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20 625FCFA qui sera utilisé pour l’épargne et faire l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The eight members of the group Sabougnouman are married women mostly in monogamous families.  The women average 43 years of age and six children each.  They all live in the seat of the rural community of Cinzana Gare, in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  They know one another through ties of kinship, marriage, their revenue-generating business in the village, and at busy fairs. The group members buy and sell peanuts, potatoes, rice, canned tomatoes (as does Djènèba Konaté), local alcoholic beverages (Dodo, made from millet), and store items (candy, OMO, soap, cookies, etc.)   With the goal of increasing their working capital in order to make their purchases in cash, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their third solidarity loan cycle.  Ms. Djènèba Konaté intends to use her loan for buying seven boxes of tomato paste each containing six cans.  She gets her supplies of tomato paste wholesale in Koutiala and sells them retail at the village fair and at the house.  Accepting cash and sometimes credit, she sells to a customer base composed generally of women.   Like the other women in the group, Djènèba hopes to make an average monthly profit of 20,625, francs CFA that will be put into savings and used to raise small ruminants.  

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying tomato paste

loans.name: Ena Del Rosario

texts.es:
Ena del Rosario L. B. es una mejer trabajadora, emprendedora y esforzada. Ella inicio vendiéndole frescos y gaseosas con una tía, luego con la ayuda de su suegra quien le regalo el carretón, el termo, los baldes, la refrigeradora y materia prima para poner su propio negocio.  Es así que desde hace ocho años inicio su negocio el cual ha ido creciendo actualmente ella invertirá en azúcar, frutas, baldes y azúcar.
 
L. como muchas mujeres nicaragüenses quienes por situaciones económicas no pudo estudiar una carrera universitaria y sus padres pues le proporcionan algún oficio, ella prendió el arte de hacer joyas es decir es orfebre actividad que realizo hasta que por la situación económica busco otro manera de sobre vivir. En la actualidad ella sueña con poder estudiar alguna carrera técnica aunque  su sueño es estudiar derechos internacionales.
texts.en:
Ena del Rosario L. Bermudez is a strong woman, a hard worker, and an entrepreneur. She started selling fruit drinks and soft drinks with an aunt, later with the help of her mother-in-law, who gave her a cart, thermos, buckets, a refrigerator, and the raw materials to make her own business. The business began eight years ago, and it has continued growing. Now, L. will invest in sugar, fruits, buckets, and ice. L., like many other Nicaraguan women who could not study in a university for economic reasons and whose parents supply them a trade, took to the art of making jewelry. She worked as a gold and silver smith until the economic situation forced her to find another livelihood. Presently, she dreams of studying a technical career although her dream is to study international law.

Translated from Spanish by Rachael Mossey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sugar, fruit, buckets, and ice

loans.name: Tweterane Women's Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en:
A determined and very hardworking A. Julius is a married man though with no children yet. He has operated a retail shop business for four years selling general merchandise in Bucuni, Kyenjojo and, at the end of every week, he is able to pocket profits totalling up to 50,000 Ugandan shillings.

Julius’s main disadvantage has been having small amount of retail stock in his business that cannot match the consumption rate of his increasing customer base. He is therefore seeking a loan that he figures will help him buy more retail stock that he hopes will satisfy the customers’ high demand and also transform his enterprise into a wholesale business.

Being very committed to his business with good customer care, Julius hopes to increase his sales revenue. This will bring about a transformation in his business and enable him to achieve a self-sustaining life and cater for his family’s requirements.

loans.use: To purchase more retail stock like sugar and soap

loans.name: Merly Rocio

texts.es:
Merly de 47 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín (lugar con montañas y caminos de tierra) de Guayaquil, tiene cuatro hijos de 11, 10, 6 y 3 años, ella tiene una lavandería.

Para poder sustentar su hogar ella tuvo que alquilar un local que sus padres le dejaron para tener dinero y comprar su primera lavadora, poco a poco con esfuerzo pudo comprarla y dejar de alquilar el local para poder trabajar con su propia lavandería.  

Con el préstamo quiere comprar detergente y suavizante para la ropa. En el futuro quiere estudiar enfermería y terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Merly is 47 years old and has four children aged 11, 10, 6 and 13 years. She owns a laundry business and lives in a peri-urban area of Guayaquil called el Fortín (a place hills and dirt roads). In order to sustain her home and work for her own laundry business, she had to rent a place she inherited from her parents. Little by little, and with effort, she was able to buy her first washing machine and stopped renting the place. With the loan, Merley wants to buy detergent and fabric softener. In the future, she wants to go nursing school and finish the construction of her house.

Translated from Spanish by Liliana Matos, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy detergent and fabric softener

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Zaituni is married with four children and all her children go to school.  She doesn’t take care of any additional family members. 

She owns a stall in Bwaise market where she sells fruit and vegetables. She has been in this business for ten years. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of fruits and vegetables to sell.  She buys from farmers who bring their produce to the very market where she works.   

Her main business challenge is the rainy season when her customers can’t reach her because she works in a muddy place. 

Zaituni joined MCDT because she wanted additional capital. She rents a two-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables like cabbages, mangoes and oranges

loans.name: Mariatou

texts.fr:
Madame  Mariatou  D.  est âgée de 40 ans et vit dans une famille monogame avec son mari et ses 4 enfants au quartier Bougouni Lafiabougou de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu à fréquenter l’école, très tôt elle commença le commerce ambulant  auprès de sa  mère qui vendait des condiments. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage et riche de cette expérience, elle commença elle aussi la vente des condiments au marché de Ségou depuis maintenant 21 ans et jouit d’une grande notoriété. 
Ces marchandises mises dans des emballages  sont  bien disposées sur une étagère et très appréciées des clients.
 C’est dans l’optique de réaliser plus de bénéfices qu’elle a fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 51 mois, après avoir fait 3 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts individuels tous correctement  remboursés. 
Elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel  qu’elle compter utiliser  pour acheter, 3 cartons de cubes maggi et  20 sacs de sel de cuisine. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako. Madame Mariatou D. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte   réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA, ce bénéfice lui servira de se prendre en charge et de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. 
Son ambition  est de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mariatou D. is 40 years old and lives in a monogamous family with her husband and their four children in the Bougouni Lafiabougou region of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having gone to school, she began in travelling sales very early alongside her mother who sold condiments. After several years of training and enriched by the experience, she too began the sale of condiments at the Ségou market at 21 years old where she enjoys a large reputation. Her merchandise, put in packaging, stays fresh on the shelf and is well-liked by her clients. With the objective of making greater profit, she has made an appeal to Soro Yiriwaso. She has had a relation with this organization for 51 months, after having taken 3 loans with others and 3 individual loans, all properly paid back. She is on her 4th individual loan which she expects to use to buy 3 cartons of Maggi broth cubes and 20 bags of cooking salt. She buys her stock in Bamako. Mrs. Mariatou D. sells for cash and for credit to both male and female customers. She expects to make a monthly profit of 120,000 FCFA, which will serve to take care of and support the needs of her family. Her ambition is to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments for food

loans.name: Catherine

texts.fr:
Madame Catherine Dembélé est âgée de 63 ans, veuve et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit chez son feu mari  dans une grande famille au quartier Pelengana Nord de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fait l’école, elle commença très tôt le petit commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage à côté de cette dernière, elle finit par embrasser le commerce de  céréales, qu’elle mène maintenant depuis  11 ans. Elle jouit d’une grande notoriété et clientèle. Elle vend au marché château près des vendeurs de condiments. Sa force de vente est due à la qualité de ses articles qui sont très prisés sur le marché.
 Afin de réaliser plus de bénéfice, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 54 mois, après  3 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts individuels correctement  remboursés. 
Elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, une tonne de riz. Elle s’approvisionne à Niono et Séribala auprès des producteurs. Madame Catherine Dembélé  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000FCFA. 
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de subvenir à ses besoins (Nourriture, habillement) surtout qu’elle est veuve depuis plusieurs années et vit avec ses petits enfants. 
Son ambition est de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Madame Catherine Dembélé is a 63 year-old widowed mother of five. She lived with her late husband in a large household in the North Pelengana quarter of Ségou (the fourth largest administrative region in the Republic of Mali). She did not attend school, and so began working with her mother at an early age, selling condiments. After many years learning the trade alongside her mother, she began selling cereals eleven years ago and has established a good reputation for herself. She sells her goods at the chateau market, alongside other condiment stalls. Her booming sales are thanks to the quality of her goods which are held in high regard. In order to generate higher profits, she has approached Soro Yiriwaso. She has been a customer of theirs for 54 months, and has received 3 community and 3 individual loans, all of which have been successfully repaid. This will be her fourth individual loan, and she aims to use it to buy a ton of rice. She sources her goods from suppliers at Niono and Séribala. Madame Catherine Dembélé takes cash and credit sales from a customer base made up of men and women. She aims to use this loan in order to generate an average monthly profit of 80 000 FCFA. This profit will enable her to see to her family's needs (food and housing), especially since losing her husband a few years ago. Her aim is to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cereals

loans.name: Coralia De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
Coralia de los Ángeles P. es una mujer trabajadora esforzada y decidida quien se dedica a la costura de cotonas, maxi, vestidos entre otros productos. Ella inicio este negocio hace catorce años con la realización de una docena de ropa en la actulidad tiene un pequeño taller donde tiene tres colaboradores.

Ella invertirá el crédito en telas e hilos para seguir progresando y lograr su sueño que es tener una mejor instalación en su taller y prosperar. Además ella está muy contenta por las oportunidades que Adim le brinda tanto en crédito como las capacitaciones que le han ayudado a administrar y empoderar su negocio.
texts.en:
Coralia de los Ángeles P. is a hardworking and determined woman who sews shirts, blankets, and dresses, among other products. She started this business 14 years ago with a dozen items of clothing. Currently she has a small shop where she works with three collaborators. She will invest the loan in fabric and thread to continue building her business and achieve her dream, which is to have a better system in her shop and prosper. Furthermore, she's very happy about the opportunities that ADIM has given her in the form of loans and training, which have helped her manage and build her business.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Richardson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric and thread

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Paula Maria

texts.es: Paula Maria de 52 años, su negocio es la venta de carne ella tiene 9 años de de realizar esta actividad pues cuando dio inicio fue por la ayuda de una de sus hijas que le  proporciono la ayuda necesaria para que avanzara con esta actividad, pues también invirtió su ahorros poco a poco con esfuerzo su negocio de fue creciendo. Actualmente está solicitando este financiamiento para la compra de materia prima que es necesaria en su negocio. Para darles un mejor servicio a los clientes ella quiere comprar una amplia variedad para ofrecer. Una de sus metas es tener su propio restaurante.
texts.en:
Paula Maria is 52 years old. She has been selling meat for nine years. One of her daughters helped her start her business, and she has gradually been able to invest her savings in it, too. Paula will use this loan to buy some of the basic supplies she needs for her business. In order to better serve her customers, she wants to offer a better variety of meats. One day, Paula would like to have her own restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Korotimi

texts.fr:
Madame Korotimi H. est âgée de 48 ans, veuve et mère de 2 enfants. Elle vit dans sa famille paternelle avec ses enfants et  d’autres ménages à  Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali)
Elle n’a pas eu à fréquenter l’école pour des raisons sociales. Alors elle commença dès sa plus jeune enfance à faire le commerce auprès de ses 2 parents. Sa mère  vendait des condiments alimentaires et son père avait une boutique de vente de céréales. 
Riche de cette expérience empirique, elle évolua seule dans le commerce d’articles divers avec l’achat vente d’atiéké, de pomme de terre, de condiments alimentaires etc. Elle mener cette activité depuis 22 ans et jouit d’une grande notoriété et clientèle. Elle est très sollicitée au marché château. 
Dans le souci de faire face à la demande clientèle, elle décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation  cette dernière depuis 42 mois, après 3 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels bien remboursés. 
Elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 660kg de pommes de terre et 1 tonne d’atiéké. Elle s’approvisionnera à Sikasso, Bamako (capitale du Mali) et en république de Côte d’Ivoire.
Madame Korotimi H. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Avec ce prêt elle envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de rembourser ses prêts et de participer à des tontines au marché en raison de 1000 FCFA par jour.
 Son ambition est de construire des maisons pour les louer.
texts.en:
Mrs. Korotimi Haidara is 48 years old, a widow and the mother of two children. She lives in her parents' household together with her children and others family members in Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mali). For social reasons, she never attended school. And so she started to be engaged in business activities early on, learning from her parents. Her mother used to sell food condiments, and her father kept a store selling cereals. With plenty of practical experience, she launched her own business selling various articles, such as “atieke” [a manioc-based food], potatoes, food condiments etc. She has been in business for 22 years now and is well known and appreciated by her customers. Her products are very much in demand at the Château market. In an effort to meet the customer demand, she decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso. She has been a client with Soro Yriwaso for 42 months and obtained three solidarity (group) loans and two individuals loans, all duly repaid. She is now on her third individual loan, which she plans to use to purchase 660 kg [1452 lbs] of potatoes and 1 ton [2200 lbs] of atieke. She stocks up in Sikasso, in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and in the Republic of Côte d’Ivoire. Mrs. Korotimi Haidara sells for cash and on credit to a customer base composed primarily of women. With this loan she plans to achieve a monthly income of 150,000 West African Francs. This revenue will allow her to repay her loans and to contribute to her market’s tontine (a savings group) at the rate of 1,000 West African Francs per day.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various items for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to stock up on millet and sugar to make beverages

loans.name: Fakye Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Simon describes himself as very hard-working. He is 32 years old and he is the leader of the “Fakye” (translated as 'Forgive') borrower group. Simon is a trader in Kente cloth. Kente cloth is a famous richly woven traditional fabric of single or multiple colors, usually worn during special occasions like festivals, parties, outdoor events and other social gatherings. He has operated his business for the past 12 years. Simon is excited to be taking out this loan, with which he plans to purchase kente cloth in bulk. He dreams of growing his business from a retail to a wholesale shop.

Simon is married to a woman who is also a trader in kente cloth and they have four children from age 4-12 years. The other members of the group are in the same business and live in the same vicinity.  They plan to invest the loan to purchase stock in bulk to grow their businesses. Simon hopes to put aside more savings to be able to provide good university and teacher training education for his children.

loans.use: To purchase kente cloth in bulk

loans.name: Kadia

texts.fr:
Madame Kadia Koné est âgée de 56 ans,  veuve et mère de 6 enfants. Elle vit chez son feu époux avec ses enfants au quartier Bagadadji près de la mosquée de Guidjo Almamy de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas été scolarisée, elle a commencé tôt le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des gâteaux à base de mil ou de riz (appelé le Takoula). Après avoir passé plusieurs années auprès de cette dernière, elle commença à s’introduire petit à petit dans la vente de céréales jusqu’à acquérir des expériences dans ce domaine. Elle jouit d’une grande clientèle  et réputation dans son quartier. Parallèlement à cette activité qu’elle mène depuis maintenant 9 ans, elle vend également des bois  de construction.
Afin de constituer du stock pour la saison pluvieuse où il y aurait une pénurie du mil, elle décide de solliciter un nouveau prêt à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est en relation depuis  54 mois  et eût   3 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts individuels, tous correctement bien remboursés. 
Ce quatrième prêt individuel sera utiliser pour acheter, 10 sacs de mil. Elle s’approvisionne sur place.
Madame Kadia Koné vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel  de 100 000FCFA, ce bénéfice  lui permettra de se prendre en charge surtout qu’elle est veuve et d’honorer à ses engagements avec Soro Yiriwaso. 
Son ambition est de pérenniser son activité si possible d’ouvrir un magasin de stockage.
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadia Koné is a 56-year-old widowed mother of six. She lives in her late husband’s home with her children in the Bagadadji area, near the Guidjo Almamy mosque in Ségou (fourth administrative region of the republic of Mali). Not having gone to school, she started selling things early on with her mother, who sold millet and rice cakes (called Takoula). After having done this for many years, she started little by little selling grains to gain experience in this domain. She enjoys a large clientele and good reputation in her neighborhood. In addition to this business, which she has been in for 9 years, she also sells construction wood. In order to build up her stock for the rainy season, when there will be a millet shortage, she has decided to seek a new loan from Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she has had a relationship for 54 months and has had 3 group loans and 3 individual loans, all of which were repaid. This fourth individual loan will be used to buy ten bags of millet. She stocks up on the premises. Mrs. Kadia Koné sells for cash and credit to a clientele composed of men and women.
